title: Duration
body: This course consists of six (6) modules each of approximately 20-45 minutes in length. It is advised that you complete one module at a sitting. Your progress will be saved and you can return to the course any time.

_items.title: Programs Branch
_items.body: The Enforcement and Intelligence Programs Directorate provides leadership, strategic direction, policy guidance and program management for the intelligence, criminal investigations and inland enforcement programs. The Directorate works to ensure that the CBSA operates optimally to realize program outcomes, including successful policy development and enforcement of program legislation, investigations and criminal prosecutions.

_items.title: Operations Branch
_items.body:
The Enforcement and Intelligence Operations Directorate delivers integrated intelligence, immigration enforcement and criminal investigations operations for the CBSA and ensures the effective, coordinated and appropriate application of enforcement resources in support of the Agency’s mandate to protect the safety and security of Canadians.

 

Together, the directorates work in tandem to plan, guide, direct and deliver integrated enforcement and intelligence priorities, programs and activities which increase the Agency’s ability to modernize and strengthen its enforcement capacity.

title: Who This Course is For and What is it Purpose
displayTitle: Who This Course is For and What is it Purpose
body:
This course is intended for new employees of the Enforcement and Intelligence community including:

  • Inland Enforcement
  • Intelligence Operations
  • Criminal Investigations

 

This course provides new employees of the Enforcement and Intelligence community with a consistent approach to interviewing which will:

  • facilitate access to greater amounts of information;
  • allow for the assessment of information reliability; and
  • ultimately lead to better decision making.

title: Overview
body:
Module 1: Structure of an Interview

  • Introduction
  • Four Phases of a Good Interview
  • Rapport
  • The Art of Clear Communication
  • Being an Effective Interviewer

Module 2: Observing

  • Non-Verbal Communication
  • Interpreting Facial Expressions
  • Interpreting Body Language
  • Arms, Hands and Legs
  • Body Language Rules

Module 3: Listening

  • Active Listening

Module 4: Detecting Deception

  • Detecting Deception
  • Non-Verbal Indicators of Deception

Module 5: Talking

  • Open and Closed Questions
  • Mirroring
  • Paraphrasing
  • Probing

Module 6: Dealing Witrh Difficult Situations

  • Difficult Situations
  • C.A.L.M. Approach

References: Some content presented in this course has been adapted from material included in the Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada course: Interviewing Techniques, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security course: Deception Detection Techniques and the book: Principles of Kinesic Interview and Interrogation, 2nd ed. by Stan B. Walters, all with permission.

title: How This Course Relates to Your Work!
displayTitle: How This Course Relates to Your Work!
body:
The ability to conduct effective interviews is an integral component of the work of E&I officers. Often, it is the best source of obtaining information regarding a file, case or investigation. Here are some examples:

To gather evidence for regulatory investigations into suspected violations of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
To gather relevant information in support of port prosecutions.
To collect information from sources in order to produce and disseminate lookouts, intelligence bulletins and alerts.
To gather information regarding Canadian employers who may be employing foreign nationals (FNs) without proper authorization.
To determine someone’s level of participation in a crime.
To produce intelligence regarding potential or suspected infractions of the laws administered by the CBSA.
To help investigate allegations of violations of the Customs Act (CA) and IRPA.
To possibly solicit someone for the CBSA’s confidential human source program.

title: Course Objectives
body:
After completing this course, you will be able to:

  • Recall the four phases of a good interview
  • Identify the qualities of an effective interviewer
  • Recognize different facial expressions
  • Identify the types and modes of the posture matrix
  • Interpret body language

 

  • List the do’s and don’ts of active listening
  • Analyze audio recordings to establish possible verbal indicators of deception
  • Recognize non-verbal indicators of deception
  • Distinguish between probing for more information and probing for veracity
  • Identify the techniques used in each phase of the C.A.L.M. approach

title: Establish and Maintain RAPPORT
body: Rapport is a good understanding of someone, including their feelings and beliefs, and an ability to communicate well with them. Building rapport is so central to successful interviewing that establishing and maintaining it is incorporated into every phase of an interview.

title: The Key to Building Rapport
body:
The process through which you contribute to building rapport with someone is called Pacing

 

Active Listening is:

  • A listening technique used to understand the content and feeling being expressed and to communicate that understanding. 
  • A structured form of listening and responding that focuses the attention on the speaker and helps people overcome their natural tendency not to listen. 
  • A process of taking in what is being said, and how words are being spoken (oral non-verbals).

title: Pacing: The Key to Building Rapport
displayTitle: Pacing: The Key to Building Rapport
body:
Pacing - is the process of transmitting someone’s behaviour back to them through our own behaviour. In other words, we move toward the other person’s model of the world.

Pacing involves getting into alignment or agreement with the other person and communicating the message: “I’m like you, you can trust me - I’m on your side”.

When used effectively, pacing enables you to achieve a higher level of empathy with the other person.

title: Pacing: The Key to Building Rapport
displayTitle: Pacing: The Key to Building Rapport
body: Pacing verbal communication can strongly influence the depth of rapport you establish with the other person.

_items.title: Vocabulary and Imagery
_items.body:
When talking with other people, it’s a good idea to incorporate as many of their words, phrases and images into your speech as you comfortably can. In doing so, you are telling the person that you understand them and they can trust you.

 

Don’t!

  • Mimic accents
  • Use vocabulary you or the other person aren’t familiar with

_items.title: Speech Rate
_items.body: Speaking rates vary considerably. Some people speak slowly, pausing to find words or phrases. Others speak rapidly and seem to have no trouble at all finding words. As you pace someone’s speech rate you will find that your thought process alters as well.

_items.title: Volume
_items.body: Pacing someone’s speech volume can be a useful tactic as people often appreciate and respect someone who speaks close to or at the same volume as them.

title: Keep in Mind!
body: If you want to change someone else’s behaviour, the best approach is to change your own.

title: Pacing Beliefs and Opinions
body:
The goal of pacing is to lead the other person in the direction you want them to go. 

Informing someone from the beginning that they are wrong may lead to defensiveness.

Instead, pace their belief (whether you agree or not) by validating a part of it or some experience related to it and then lead with your suggestion.

 

Remember:

It’s much easier and more effective to move from agreement to disagreement than from disagreement to agreement.

title: When Not to Pace
body:
Situations or things you should not pace:

  • When your tactic isn’t working, try something else.
  • Something that you’re not comfortable with.
  • Stuttering, limping, asthmatic breathing etc.
  • Accents, tics, nervous mannerisms etc.

title: Outcomes of Pacing and Rapport
body:
Pacing creates a favourable environment for your ideas and suggestions because what you are doing is accepting the other person. You’re implying that you speak the same language, are on the same wave length and are sharing a common experience.

Your acceptance of them leads to their acceptance of you.

title: Leading
body:
Once you have achieved rapport with someone, they are likely to follow the next step you take. If your objective is to persuade the person or propose a different perspective to them then you must lead. 

Pace first - then lead 

Meet the person where they already are and then suggest new options.

title: How to Test for Rapport
body:
Before trying to lead someone it is a good idea to first find out if you have effectively established rapport. This can be done subtly and at the non-verbal level.

 

Example:

Their response could be to mirror your new posture, or it might be a different shift to restore balance to the relationship. 

What you are looking for is a congruent or complementary response.

title: Posture Example
body:
Step 1

Pace the other person for a short time, a few minutes is sufficient.
 

Step 2

Then change your posture.

 

Step 3

Wait to see if and how they respond.

 

Their response could be to mirror your new posture, or it might be a different shift to restore balance to the relationship.

What you are looking for is a congruent or complementary response.

title: How Other People Understand
body:
One way of looking at how people understand is the four (4) modes of perception approach:

  • Thinking
  • Feeling
  • Intuition
  • Sensation

Thinking and feeling are placed at opposite ends of one axis and intuition and sensation at opposite ends of the other axis.

People use all four of these modes. Someone can be characterized as being guided predominantly by thinking and sensation or intuition and feeling.

title: Dominant Perceptual Mode
body:
The process can be described this way:

When you make initial contact with someone, that person will probably be thinking in one of the three main representational systems.

Internally they will be generating visual images, having feelings, or talking to themselves and hearing sounds.

title: How to Identify Perceptual Modes
body:
One of the simplest ways to identify another person’s dominant perceptual mode is to pay close attention to the words, phrases and images they use.

If you have past experience as a BSO working at a port of entry, you already have exposure to asking questions and paying close attention to what the person says and how they say it.

title: Dominant Perceptual Mode
body:
Predominant Mode

 

Examples of Words or Images Used

Visual

 

“I can see how the situation looks to you”

“The idea looked good to me at the time”

“I want the big picture…we’ll focus on details later”

“My point of view is that…”

Auditory

 

“Tell me again…I’m not sure I heard you right”

“That sounds like a good idea”

“Let me use you as a sounding board for an idea I have”

“Yes that’s clear as a bell”

“Something just went click in my mind”

Feeling

 

“I got the sense that something wasn’t quite right”

“That idea feels right”

“I can’t get a handle on this concept”

“That detail doesn’t sit well with me”

title: Practicing and Establishing Rapport
body:
Building rapport is very important to the success of an interview and obtaining the information you require from the other person. It basically allows the person to trust you, and people want to talk to and tell the truth to people they trust.

What are some tips for practicing and establishing rapport? 

Write your thoughts in the box provided, then press “submit” to see some suggested answers.

title: Tips for Practicing and Establishing Rapport
displayTitle: Tips for Practicing and Establishing Rapport
body:
• Practice one thing at a time - mood, body language, rate of speech etc.
  • Many people find speech rate easiest to pace, try it first.
  • Use television shows to practice pacing the body positions of someone on screen.

title: The Art of Clear Communication
body:
In order to get people to understand what you mean, you first need to understand… 

how they understand, or at least how they try to understand. 

When you understand how other people process information you can organize your communication in a way that fits their mode of perception.

title: The Art of Clear Communication
body:
“Misunderstandings can result when people automatically assume that others think as they do”
- Robert Sommer,
The Mind's Eye

title: Use of Audio
body:
Audio and video recordings with sound are included in parts of this course.

Please ensure that your headset or speakers are turned on to a comfortable volume level.

title: Four Phases of a Good Interview

_items.title: Phase 1 - Orientation
_items.body:
There are four (4) goals in this phase:

  • Establish the purpose of the interview.
  • Formally identify the person involved in the interview.
  • Establish an adequate level of language comprehension.
  • Establish rapport with the person being interviewed.

The four goals of the orientation phase do not have to follow the presented sequence. You can develop your own style and format.

Of the four goals, the fourth - establishing rapport - is the most important.

Rapport is essential for establishing an interviewee’s baseline which is an important factor when trying to detect deception.

_items.title: Phase 2 - Narration
_items.body:
There are two (2) goals in this phase:

  1. Maintain or enhance rapport.
  2. Get the interviewee talking.

Also called the “listening phase”, the interviewee should be doing most of the talking while the interviewer uses techniques to encourage them to be as forthcoming as possible, expand on their story and to stay on topic.

The information obtained during this phase is used to formulate more specific and probing questions in later phases of the interview.  

This phase provides the opportunity for interviewers to:

  • analyze verbal and non-verbal content and behaviours; and,
  • note areas/topics to revisit and probe later on in the interview.

Do - Remain Neutral

Don’t - React to or confront possible deception

_items.title: Phase 3 - Cross Examination
_items.body:
There is one (1) goal in this phase:

  1. Probe the interviewee for more specific details to seek clarification of statements made in the narration phase.

The interviewer focuses on areas that were missing, vague, inconsistent, not credible, lacking detail or were accompanied by clusters of verbal or non-verbal behaviours that were inconsistent with the interviewee’s baseline.

During this phase of the interview it is important to probe topics/issues until you are satisfied with the answers provided.

This phase should remain non-accusatory in order to collect as much information as possible. Confronting deception should be reserved for the next phase of the interview.

_items.title: Phase 4 - Resolution
_items.body:
There is one (1) goal in this phase:

  1. Get the interviewee to accept the established truths or exposed deceptions.

During this phase, the interviewer confronts the interviewee with possible deception and tries to get them to disclose what they have attempted to conceal or disguise.

title: Introduction to Interviewing
body:
The interviewing skills and process presented in this course will allow you to:

Obtain more information and assess its reliability with more certainty because it focuses on understanding the vocabulary of the body as well as the person’s verbal output and the content of what is being said.

title: What is an interview?
body: An interview is a non-accusatory process  during which an interviewer asks questions designed to develop factual information such as, who, what, where, when and how from a willing participant. It also provides the opportunity to assess the interviewee’s verbal and non-verbal behaviours. The purpose of conducting interviews is to efficiently obtain and confirm as much information as possible and to assess its credibility.

title: Module Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Recall the four phases of a good interview
  • Identify the qualities of an effective interviewer

title: What is an interview?
body: Successful interviewers are those who know these four phases and their objectives and can successfully accomplish those objectives in every interview.

title: The Role of Rapport in Everyday Life
displayTitle: The Role of Rapport in Everyday Life
body:
When people encounter one another an automatic mechanism (conscious and subconscious) immediately starts, triggering a process of comparison and identification with one another.

If the outcome of this process is positive overall, a positive rapport is established between the two people. 

When people are in a state of good rapport they tend to respond more positively to stimulations, proposals and to the other person in general.

title: The Role of Rapport for CBSA E&I Officers
displayTitle: The Role of Rapport for CBSA E&I Officers
body:
CBSA E&I officers don’t necessarily have access to the same investigative tools (certain databases etc.) used by police forces; therefore, interviews are often the best source of information.

Establishing rapport with the interviewee increases the chances of obtaining the required information to make appropriate decisions and take appropriate actions.

title: Secrets of Rapport
body:
Conformation is at the heart of establishing rapport. This concept is based on the fact that a person tends to conform to another’s behaviour.

This happens through a comparison of your own model of the world with what you receive from the experience of the ongoing interaction.

 

Symbiosis - One of the signs of the presence of rapport is the tendency of people who are interacting  to come to a behavioural compromise or meeting point.

Long-term experience of - and exposure to - mutual rapport generates a true and permanent behavioural symbiosis.

title: Dominant Perceptual Mode
body:
Each of us has, at any one time, a dominant or primary mode of perception. What do you think those might be?

Type your answers in the space provided below and then press “submit” to see the answers.

_feedback.correct:
Visual

Auditory

Feeling

_incorrect.final:
Visual

Auditory

Feeling

title: How to Get Others to Understand You
displayTitle: How to Get Others to Understand You
body:
When you use the other person’s dominant perceptual mode, they will respond.

Sometimes it’s not apparent which form of communication someone will respond to. In that case, you can use a trial and error approach.

By varying your strategies and having the range to cover all modes of perception you will be able to reach most people most of the time, and they will clearly understand what you want.

title: Active Listening for Clear Communication
body:
An important strategy in effectively communicating what you mean to another person, and ensuring that you understand what the other person means, is active listening.

To listen actively to someone means that you learn to see, hear, and feel in the same way that he sees, hears, and feels. In effect, it is another form of pacing; of establishing rapport.  

By pacing, or synchronising, your mood, body language, speech rate, and even breathing with the other person, you achieve strong rapport while maximizing mutual understanding.

title: Tips for Practicing Clear Communication Techniques
displayTitle: Tips for Practicing Clear Communication Techniques
body:
• During conversations with colleagues and friends or while listening to the radio or television, pay attention to the words and phrases people use to describe their experiences. Try to identify their dominant perceptual modes.

 

  • Keep a notebook to jot down words and phrases that indicate perceptual modes.

 

  • Practice using the same words and phrases that others use during your conversations with them. Vary this practice by choosing different words while remaining within the same perceptual mode.
     
  • In your conversations with others, practice active listening. Reflect back to them your understanding of what they have said or intended, while remaining in their dominant perceptual mode.

​​​​​​​

  • Pacing some of their behaviours might also strengthen the bond of rapport you are creating.

title: Being an Effective Interviewer
body:
A good interviewer should have an interest in human nature and a personality that enables them to gain the cooperation of the other person.

Let’s explore some of the qualities and traits!

Some of these will come naturally to you during interviews, but others might not. Your abilities can improve if you’re willing to devote time to studying and practicing.

title: Being an Effective Interviewer
body: Discover the 9 qualities of an effective interviewer.

_items.title: Motivation
_items.body:
Motivation is the most significant factor in the success achieved during an interview. Without motivation other qualities lose their significance. Guard yourself against boredom, cynicism and be confident that the person will cooperate.  

You must constantly be aware of the shifting attitudes that normally characterize the person’s reaction to the interview. Note the person’s every gesture, word, and voice inflection and attempt to determine why the person is in a certain mood or why a change of mood has occurred.

Look for: 

  • any tendency to resist further questioning;
  • diminishing resistance;
  • contradictions; and
  • non-verbal cues.

_items.title: Patient and tactful
_items.body:
If you are a patient and tactful interviewer you can increase the chances of success by building a good rapport with the person, who in turn, will be more inclined to talk freely.


The more the person talks, the easier it is to judge the validity of their statements and the motivation to talk may become more apparent.

_items.title: Maintain a calm, neutral and objective attitude
_items.body:
As an interviewer you should maintain a calm, neutral and objective attitude regardless of the emotional reactions that the person may be experiencing or which may be simulated during the interview.


Everything you do should be geared towards achieving the purpose of the interview.

_items.title: Initiative
_items.body:
To be successful, you need to seize and maintain the initiative during the interview. 

You will always have certain advantages at the beginning; however, you should strive to maintain the initiative by:

Using appropriate interviewing techniques
Exercising self-control
Exposing the person’s weaknesses as they become apparent
Displaying consistently an attitude of confidence and self-assurance.

_items.title: Adaptable
_items.body:
As an interviewer you must be able to adapt yourself to the different personalities of the person/people you are interviewing. 

Being adaptable allows you to smoothly shift your techniques and approaches during interviews. This can be helpful if certain techniques are not eliciting the information you are looking for.

_items.title: Perseverant
_items.body:
Being perseverant can make the difference between you being an average interviewer or excellent interviewer.

If you are easily discouraged by opposition, non-cooperation, or other difficulties your chances of a successful conclusion to your interview will decrease significantly.

Don’t give up, change it up!

_items.title: Professional
_items.body:
Your personal appearance and behavior can greatly influence the conduct of the interview and the attitude of the person you are interviewing. A firm, deliberate, business-like and professional manner of speech and attitude will create a proper environment for a successful interview.

If your manner reflects fairness, strength, efficiency and understanding, the person is more likely to be cooperative and receptive to questioning.

_items.title: Strong communication skills
_items.body:
As with many other aspects of your work, in order to be an effective interviewer you must be able to prepare and present written and oral reports in a clear, complete, concise, and accurate manner. In other words, you need to have strong communication skills.

Often the interviews you conduct are just one component of a case or file you are working on. Their full value may only be realized with the timely dissemination of the obtained information, in a usable form, to the appropriate people or agencies.

_items.title: Self-control
_items.body:
As an interviewer it is necessary for you to have or demonstrate a high degree of self-control in order to avoid displays of genuine anger, irritation or weariness that may cause you to lose the initiative during the interview.

This quality is especially important when using techniques that require the display of simulated emotions or attitudes such as pacing and mirroring.

title: Interviewer Pitfalls
body: Many factors can affect the outcome of an interview. Here we’ll explore some potential pitfalls to be aware of. Awareness might help you avoid them and add to the success of your interviews.

_items.title: Terminology
_items.body:
Studies have proven that questions asked and the terminology used can tremendously affect the outcome of an interview or the information retrieved.

Be careful of not only what you ask but also how you ask it (terminology). We do not want false information; we are seeking the truth.

 

Example:

Participants shown a video of a car accident were interviewed regarding what they had seen. The results showed that when the interviewer used the terms “when the car was hit, the information retrieved was accurate and forthcoming.

When the interviewer changed the main verb to “smashed”, implying that the accident was of a more serious nature than it actually was, participants offered a larger volume of information, a large portion of which was inaccurate.

_items.title: Stereotyping
_items.body:
Stereotypes are simple, one-dimensional portrayals of people usually based on gender, race, religion, sexual orientation, profession, age etc. which often lead to prejudice. 

We all stereotype people to some degree as we try to make sense of the world. 

Stereotypes are not always necessarily negative, and positive stereotypes can be also be dangerous.

 

For example:

Negative: All people of a certain culture lie.

Positive: Senior citizens returning from winter holidays down south never smuggle drugs.

Stereotyping:

is inaccurate and often derogatory.
prejudges a person’s ability, skills, and personality based on unfair assumptions. 

 

To be fair, an individual should be judged on their merit regardless of race, religious beliefs, colour, gender, physical and/or mental disability, marital status, family status, source of income, age, ancestry, place of origin, or sexual orientation.

Some examples of stereotypes are:

Someone wearing a suit is a business person.
Someone with tattoos is a criminal.

_items.title: Partisanship
_items.body:
Partisanship is your personal preferences, what you personally like versus what you dislike. We are constantly making judgements based on our own likes and dislikes. 

Example: When English and Scottish fans were interviewed after a soccer match, the majority believed their country’s team had played the game better even though one had lost by a large margin.

Some examples of people that might be treated differently based on their occupation are:

  • Priest
  • Minister or other religious leader
  • Police officer or other law enforcement officer
  • Public official
  • Politician 
  • Celebrity

 

Important tips to remember are as follows: 

  • Be aware of your own personal preferences and do not let them influence your judgement towards the person you are interviewing.
  • All we should be interested in is the truth.
  • Do not let your judgment be clouded.
  • Do not be intimidated and do not be afraid to pursue what areas of interest need to be probed. 
  • Trust your experience and intuition and continue until you are satisfied.

_items.title: Script Memory
_items.body:
Instead of having to remember and encode all the details of each new event we encounter, we simply rely on the script we have in our memory and only take in new distinctive information. 

Script memory, while not thoroughly reliable, can help us filter, organize, and process large amounts of information quickly and efficiently, but can also negatively affect accurate recall of information.

Treat each situation as if it were new to you. Be detail-oriented!

 

For example:

When going to a friend’s house you can quickly spot what is new because you “remember” what the house looked like before on your last visit.

_items.title: Emotional Factors
_items.body:
Your emotional state can impact 
the effectiveness of an interview. 
We all have days when we are 
upset, tired, annoyed, or are 
affected by any number of other 
emotions. Your state of mind can negatively or positively impact the effectiveness of an interview.

The goal is to:

  • Project a sympathetic, friendly, and compassionate image. 
  • Win the person’s trust and create a conversational rapport. 
  • Create a psychological atmosphere that will facilitate the free-flow of conversation.
  • Be aware of your state of mind and do your best to put aside your personal problems so that you can focus on the task at hand.

title: Next Steps
body: Now that you have learned about the structure of an interview, the art of clear communication and qualities of an effective interviewer, you have some of the fundamentals on which you can base your interviews. In the next module of this course, you will be introduced to the topic of “Observing”.

title: Observing
body:
A person is rarely aware of their posture, gestures, movements and facial expression.  Someone’s body language can be telling one story while their words are telling a completely different story. 

The story being told by the body is often the reliable one. 

You can become a master communicator by learning to read body language and through awareness of your own.

title: Non-Verbal Communication
body:
Most of us are aware that both verbal and non-verbal communication exist and that we use them in our conversations and interactions with other people.

But what percentage of our communicated meaning do you think comes from each?

Enter your answers in the boxes provided below.

_feedback.correct:
Verbal Communication

45%

Non-Verbal Communication

55%

Experts estimate that 45% of our communicated meaning comes from what we say and as much as 55% comes from our body language!

_incorrect.final:
Verbal Communication

45%

Non-Verbal Communication

55%

Experts estimate that 45% of our communicated meaning comes from what we say and as much as 55% comes from our body language!

title: Module Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Recognize different facial expressions
  • Identify the types and modes of the posture matrix
  • Interpret body language

title: Interpreting Facial Expressions
body:
Someone’s face can communicate without using language. In fact, it has the potential to communicate more non-verbal meaning than any other component of body language.

The face expresses emotion the best, followed by the hands, and then the total body.

title: Universal Expressions
body:
Paul Ekman is a psychologist and pioneer in the study of emotions and their relation to facial expressions. He discovered that there are seven (7) universal emotions expressed in faces from any culture.


Let’s take a look at them!

_items.title: Anger
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Forehead: No wrinkles due to the pulling down of the eyebrows (required) 
  • Eyebrows: Furrowed (required); may cause vertical or horizontal wrinkling in between brows due to the furrowing (optional) 
  • Eyes: penetrating stare quality, open wide - but because of the lowering and moving together of the eyebrows, this eyelid widening may just look "glaring" rather than the classic wide-eyed effect (required)  

 

Middle face

  • No clearly distinguishing features 

 

Lower face

  • Mouth: Lips are tense (required) 
  • Jaw is closed, could be thrust forward (optional) 
  • Lips pressed together; may create bulges in upper and lower mouth area (optional)

_items.title: Contempt
_items.body:
Contempt is always one-sided; unilateral

 

Upper face

  • Nothing distinguishing

 

Middle face

  • Nothing distinguishing

 

Lower face

  • Mouth: Tightening or puckering of the lip corner with the corner of the lip slightly angled upward; occurs only on one side of the mouth; unilateral (required)
  • Both lip corners may be slightly angled up, but still with only one corner tightened or puckered. (optional)

_items.title: Disgust
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Eyebrows: lowered due to muscle movement crinkling the nose (optional)

 

Middle face

  • Nasolabial furrow is deepened (required)
  • Nose crinkled (usually due to a high-intensity upper lip raise) (optional)

 

Lower face

  • Upper lip raised; can be bilateral or unilateral (required)

_items.title: Distress (sadness)
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Wrinkles concentrated in the center of the forehead (required)
  • Raised INNER corners of eyebrows (required); which can create a slight diagonal shape (optional)
  • Pulling together of the eyebrows paired with the raising of the inner corners of the brow; this may cause vertical wrinkling in between the brows (optional)
  • Wrinkles or dimples may appear just above the inner corners of the brows due to the isolated inner corner raise (optional)

 

Lower face

  • Lip corners angled down  (optional)

_items.title: Fear
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Forehead: Horizontal wrinkles extend much of the way across the entire forehead (due to the raising of the entire eyebrow) (required)
  • Eyebrows: Inner and outer eyebrows are raised up and drawn in together; this causes the eyebrows to appear straighter across. (required); eyebrows can have a squiggled effect (a slight dip in the center of the brow); this is due to the pulling up and in of the brow. (optional)
  • Eyes: The eyes may have a wider, tenser appearance; the eyelids could be raised, which will reveal more of the whites of the eyes. (optional)

 

Lower face

  • Mouth: Lip corners are sharply pulled back and down; may be bilateral or unilateral; open or closed mouth (required); the corners of the mouth being pulled back and down may cause small wrinkles to occur just below the lip corners. (optional)
  • Neck muscles may appear to be strained or tightened. (optional)

_items.title: Surprise
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Forehead: Wrinkles running across - usually all the way across (due to the eyebrow lift) (required)
  • Eyebrows: Entirely raised creating an arched, curved appearance (caused by the pulling upward motion of the brows) (required)
  • Eyes: Wide - Could be due to the pulling up of the eyebrows in lower intensities (required)

 

Middle face

  • No distinctive features

 

Lower face

  • Mouth: Jaw is relaxed, may be dropped - often referred to as slack jaw (required)
  • Lips: Typically parted, but can be closed (optional)

_items.title: Happiness
_items.body:
Upper face

  • Wrinkles in the corners of the eyes, crow's-feet (required)
  • Bagging under eyes (required)

 

Middle face

  • Cheeks raised (required)
  • Nasolabial furrow has more definition (required)

 

Lower face

  • Corners of lips are pulled back and slightly angled up (required)

title: Facial Expressions
body:
Paraphrased excerpts from Emotions Revealed, Recognizing Faces and Feelings to Improve Communication and Emotional Life by Paul Ekman. 

Most of us can recognize emotional expressions in the face and voice if the expressions are intense and the person showing the expression is not attempting to diminish or conceal signs of emotion, but often, that is not the case.

title: Slight or Partial Expressions
body:
When an emotion is just beginning to be experienced, and that emotion is not intense, it may show in a very slight expression in which the muscles are not contracted very much, or it may register as partial expression, evident in just one area of the face but not across the entire face in a full expression. 

 

Note:

Not all emotions, when they first begin to be experienced, are low intensity; it is possible for an emotion to be very strong right from the start.

 

A slight or partial expression may also occur when someone is trying to regulate or diminish their emotional expressions.

When you see a slight or partial expression, you can assume it’s either just beginning or being regulated to appear weaker.

title: Micro Facial Expressions
body:
If someone is trying to eliminate any and all signs of emotion, the act of doing so may actually result in a very brief micro expression. Typically it only lasts for a fifth of a second or less.

Micro expressions occur when a person is consciously trying to conceal all signs of how they are feeling.

They may also occur when the inhibition of expression occurs outside of consciousness, when the person doesn’t consciously know how they are feeling.

Micro expressions may be very brief full expressions or may be very brief partial and/or slight expressions. The combination of all three - micro (very brief), partial (only registered in one area), and slight (not much muscular contraction) - are the hardest to recognize.

But you can learn!

title: How Did You Do?
body:
Micro expressions can be very brief and subtle. The intent of the clips was to try to mimic real life. 

If you had difficulty discerning the expressions you may want to retry the quiz.

title: Interpreting Body Language
body: The body does not “talk” as much as the face, but it tells the truth.

title: Posture
body: In trying to deceive another person, most control is exercised on the face, with increasingly less control demonstrated in hands and body.

title: Posture
body:
This means that the face may be most expressive. But it is also the best liar. Because of this, posture and the positioning of arms, hands, legs, and feet are valuable sources of meaning for the interviewer.

There are two basic indicators of body language:

  • leaning forward or backward; and
  • having an open or closed position.

Leaning forward is active while leaning back is passive participation. An open posture is positive, while a closed posture portrays a negative attitude.

_graphic.alt: Two person that one has their arms open and the other closed

title: Posture - Open/Closed
body:
People showing open hands, fully facing you with both feet planted on the ground are accepting.

People with arms folded , legs crossed and bodies turned away are signaling that they are rejecting messages or are feeling defensive.

_graphic.alt: One person sitting on a chair. One has their posture foreward which signified he's engaged and the other person has their back backwards which signified he's disengaged

title: Posture - Engaged/Disengaged
body:
This posture indicates whether people are actively or passively reacting to communication.

Leaning forward and pointing towards you means they are actively engaged.

Leaning back and looking up at the ceiling means they are less engaged and are either passively absorbing the message or ignoring it.

title: Posture Matrix
body:
The two groups of postures combine into four different postures:

  • Open/Engaged: The responsive mode. This person is actively accepting.
  • Closed/Engaged: The combative mode. This person is actively resisting, ready for argument, ready to contradict.
  • Closed/Disengaged: The constrained mode. This person is passively resisting, perhaps escaping into his own thoughts.
  • Open/Disengaged: The reflective mode. This person is receptive but less engaged.


The image is divided in four quadrants:

  1. The first quadrant represents a Reflective posture (Open and Disengaged).
  2. The second quadrant represents a Responsive posture (Open and Engaged).
  3. The third quadrant represents a Constrained posture (Disengaged and Closed).
  4. The fourth quadrant represents a Combative posture (Engaged and Closed).

_items.text: Match the name of the posture with the image by dragging and dropping each name on the corresponding image.

title: Arms, Hands, Legs and Feet - What Are They Saying?
body: Within the basic postures, there are specific positions involving the arms, hands, legs, and feet that have specific interpretations. Let’s take a look at them.

_items.title: Arms Crossed
_items.body:
This is a defensive gesture exhibited when someone feels uncomfortable and wants to protect themselves. It may also mean the person is closing off to you. When a person doesn’t feel secure, they try to take up less physical space. 

Unless the temperature in the room is cold and people have crossed their arms to stay warm, those with their arms folded across their chest are saying they are holding onto their position, bracing themselves, which means they are closed off to any position you may offer. This stance is also accompanied by nervousness and tension. So when you see someone with arms folded across their chest, it means the person is withdrawing.

_items.title: Arms Akimbo
_items.body: When the arms are placed on the hips and the elbows protrude from the sides of the body, it means, “Stay away from me” or “Don’t mess with me.” It is, as anthropologist Desmond Morris says, “an anti-embrace posture.” It is also a display of extreme confidence and independence.

_items.title: Arms Open
_items.body:
Clasping the arms behind the back shows openness; people in this posture signal that they feel no need to protect themselves. On walkabouts where they meet with their subjects, the British Royal family often display this stance, torso exposed and arms at bay, indicating they are at ease.

This position presents a show of confidence. Soldiers often assume this stance with their hands clasped behind their backs when they are ordered to stand at ease. They are relaxed, open, and have nothing to hide.

_items.title: Arms Flailing
_items.body: In many Mediterranean and Middle Eastern cultures, flailing arms are often used to express certain points during a conversation, as part of normal communication. But arms flailing in Western cultures may mean something completely different: that a person is out of control, highly emotional, or extremely angry.

_items.title: Hidden Hands
_items.body: When a person hides their hands while speaking - such as putting them in their pockets - they may be hiding valuable information or not wanting to reveal something personally important.

_items.title: Angry Hands
_items.body:
Clenching the fist tends to mean that a person is not revealing their emotions verbally. A clenched hand while someone is speaking may also mean the person is truly angry or upset.

If the clenched fist hides the thumb, the person may be feeling threatened, intimidated, or worried. Holding onto the thumbs in a fist-like position is a protective device, much like crossing the arms. Pointing outward with the pointer finger or employing jerky hand movements when speaking also signifies someone is harboring anger.

_items.title: “Lying” Hands
_items.body:
A person who is not being forthright is usually less expressive with their hands, which may be clenched, made into a fist, or kept folded or in the pockets. Notice how tightly a person has their hands clasped while talking: the tighter, the more tense someone is.

When a person is clutching something, such as a chair, it is as though they are trying to hold onto reality. People who are holding onto themselves are tense or insecure and are literally trying to ‘get a grip’. In so doing, they may be engaging in a lie or attempting to avoid experiencing powerful emotions.

_items.title: “Honest” Hands
_items.body:
Conversely, when a person is being truthful, the palms of their hands will be exposed and the fingers will usually be extended. This shows openness and an interest in others.

It is an accepting gesture and means the person is receptive and welcoming of you and your ideas. Showing the palm is also a sign that makes you more vulnerable to another person. On the other hand, a person who shows you the back of the hand is usually not being as receptive and open, but is closed off.

_items.title: Pressured Hands
_items.body:
These unconscious gestures are what people do when they feel pressured, even though their inner turmoil may not be apparent in the conversation. 

These gestures may also be a sign of anger and frustration. Nail mutilation, biting or picking at cuticles, hand wringing, and fidgeting also indicate anxiousness.

_items.title: Bored Hands
_items.body: Someone who is feeling frustrated or bored may twiddle the thumbs, with the fingers interlocked and the thumbs rotating around each other. This physical action is an attempt to relieve boredom.

_items.title: Confident Hands
_items.body: A self-assured person often exhibits numerous hand gestures that reflect confidence. Steepling (touching the fingertips of each hand together to form a steeple) is a self-assured gesture often used by teachers, ministers, politicians, lawyers, and those responsible for disseminating information. People who negotiate also use this gesture.

title: Legs and Feet
body: Now that you have examined the body language of the upper body, arms and hands, let’s take a look at the lower body and more specifically, the legs and feet.

_items.title: Confident Legs
_items.body:
Legs that are apart when a person sits signal openness and confidence. When a woman is wearing a skirt, the legs will be less apart for obvious reasons. If the legs are together and closed at the knees, it indicates an openness and sense of self-assuredness. 

If both feet are on the ground and pointing toward the other person with the knees together, it demonstrates frankness and honesty. Confidence and self-assuredness in both men and women are apparent if the legs are crossed, but only if one knee is crossed directly over the other.

_items.title: “Lying” Legs
_items.body:
When someone’s leg is crossed above the knee, the person is grounding or bracing themselves. 
This means they may not be confident or may not be telling the truth about something.

_items.title: Get-Me-Out-Of-Here Legs
_items.body: Let’s say you are speaking to someone who is facing you and looking at you, with head and torso in your direction. But you notice that the person’s legs and feet are pointed in the opposite direction. What you have observed is that this person wants to leave and doesn’t really want to talk to you. When a person is uncomfortable with you, their legs literally move toward the door to escape.

_items.title: Independent Legs
_items.body: An informal position like this indicates an independent free spirit kind of a person.

_items.title: Dominant Legs
_items.body: Legs stretched out in front, whether crossed or not, shows the person is being dominant. Those who sit in this manner may be strong-willed people who may exhibit bullyish behaviour. There appears to be a self-centered manner in their attempt to be noticed.

_items.title: “Honest” Feet
_items.body: Flat on the floor, no movement, slightly open, facing the person.

_items.title: Impatient Feet
_items.body: Foot jiggling. This is like the get-me-out-of-here legs, the person is impatient and ready to get going and start to be active.

_items.title: Nervous Feet
_items.body: Foot locking. When a person is feeling nervous or uncomfortable, they will lock their foot behind the leg no matter how relaxed the upper body is. The foot position is a sign of nervousness.

_items.title: Restrained Feet
_items.body: Ankle locking may mean the person is holding back. Quite often this is associated with somebody needing to go to the bathroom and are literally sort of holding on.

title: Remember
body:
• Communication is 45% verbal (the words we speak) and 55% non-verbal (our body language).
  • Facial expressions are the best indicators of emotions while posture and movements usually tell the most reliable story.
  • We are usually more aware of facial expressions and less aware of the story being told by posture and movements.

title: Body Language Rules
body:
If you see a person placing their hand over their mouth. What does it mean? 

  • Tiredness? 
  • Bad breath? 
  • Lying?
  • Holding back?

 

It could be any of those. To read body language accurately you must apply two important rules:

  • Clusters 
  • Context

title: Clusters
body:
One of the most serious mistakes someone can make in interpreting body language is to interpret a solitary gesture in isolation from other gestures or circumstances.

Examining a cluster of gestures is essential for a correct reading. 

Let’s look at an example.

title: Clusters
body:
Example:

A politician standing behind a podium with his arms tightly folded across his chest and his chin lowered. As he tells a group of young people how receptive he is to new ideas he brings his hand up and touches his mouth briefly.

 

Using what you’ve learned about non-verbal communication, write down your thoughts on the body language and gestures of the politician in the example.

_feedback.correct:
A politician standing behind a podium (blocked) with his arms tightly folded across his chest (defensive) and his chin lowered (hostile). As he tells a group of young people how receptive he is to new ideas he brings his hand up and touches his mouth briefly (lying).

 

Four (4) separate but consistent body language indicators contradict his verbal message and suggest that he is not receptive. Any one of these taken on their own might not have meant anything.


Taken all together they are significant. This is an example of how observation of clusters of indicators is the key to interpreting body language.

_incorrect.final:
A politician standing behind a podium (blocked) with his arms tightly folded across his chest (defensive) and his chin lowered (hostile). As he tells a group of young people how receptive he is to new ideas he brings his hand up and touches his mouth briefly (lying).

 

Four (4) separate but consistent body language indicators contradict his verbal message and suggest that he is not receptive. Any one of these taken on their own might not have meant anything.


Taken all together they are significant. This is an example of how observation of clusters of indicators is the key to interpreting body language.
_incorrect.notFinal:
A politician standing behind a podium (blocked) with his arms tightly folded across his chest (defensive) and his chin lowered (hostile). As he tells a group of young people how receptive he is to new ideas he brings his hand up and touches his mouth briefly (lying).

 

Four (4) separate but consistent body language indicators contradict his verbal message and suggest that he is not receptive. Any one of these taken on their own might not have meant anything.


Taken all together they are significant. This is an example of how observation of clusters of indicators is the key to interpreting body language.

title: Clusters
body:
Being aware of the context in which the body language occurs is essential.

Sometimes the physical reality of the context produces the body language and there is no deeper psychological reason. 

Picture a person sitting in a bus station, arms and legs crossed, hunched forward. It could be that the person is feeling acutely defensive and insecure. 

OR

It could be January and the bus station has no heating.

Context matters!

body:

title: How Did You Do?
body:
Being able to accurately interpret non-verbal communication and body language takes practice. 

Try incorporating it into your daily life, observing a family member, someone on the bus you take, or someone being interviewed on the television. There are plenty of opportunities.

title: Next Steps
body:
Whether you’re interviewing someone who is talkative or reserved, being able to interpret non-verbal communication is an essential skill as body language is present no matter how much or little the person speaks.

In the next module you’ll learn about active listening which includes not only examining what is said but how the words are spoken.

title: Listening
body:
I like to listen. I have learned a great deal from listening. Most people never listen.
(Ernest Hemingway)

Seek first to understand, then to be understood.
(Stephen Covey)

title: Introduction
body:
We spend years learning how to read, write and speak. But few of us have had any training on how to listen. Yet psychologists all agree that listening is the second most difficult skill to learn next to reading. 

Furthermore, listening is a very important skill, especially for people who conduct interviews. 

Improving your listening skills will: 

  • Help you get more information and cooperation from people. 
  • Reduce the likelihood of having misunderstandings.
  • Help you assess a person’s credibility.
  • Make your interviews more productive.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • List the do’s and don’ts of active listening

title: Listening is Difficult
body:
Sometimes listening is easy. For example, listening to your favorite CD or listening to a dynamic speaker talk about something that fascinates you. However, most of the time listening is not so easy. It requires energy and concentration. 

Why do you think it may be difficult for people to listen? 
Write your thoughts in the box provided, then press “submit” to see some suggested answers.

Why is listening difficult? Enter your thoughts and press submit to see suggested answers.

title: Listening is Difficult
body:
• We are bored with what is being said. 
  • We are distracted. 
  • We are tired. 
  • We are more interested in expressing our ideas than understanding the other person’s ideas. 
  • Our emotions get in the way.

title: Listening is Difficult
body:
• We think we have already heard enough to understand. 
  • We don’t have enough time. 
  • We don’t need to or don’t care to know. 
  • We don’t really value what the person is saying. 
  • We think we already know what the person will say. 
  • We have difficulty understanding what is being said.

title: Active Listening
body: Active listening can be used to address these possible difficulties in listening and improve your listening skills.

_items.title: So what is Active Listening?
_items.body:
Active Listening is:

  • A listening technique used to understand the content and feeling being expressed and to communicate that understanding. 
  • A structured form of listening and responding that focuses the attention on the speaker and helps people overcome their natural tendency not to listen. 
  • A process of taking in what is being said, and how words are being spoken (oral non-verbals).

title: Active Listening Tips Activity 1/2
body:

title: Things to Avoid When Actively Listening
displayTitle: Things to Avoid When Actively Listening
body:
Let’s conclude this module with:
Things to Avoid when Actively Listening 

  1. Interrupting 
  2. Completing the person’s sentences 
  3. Allowing your body language to send the wrong message, such as: 
  • I’m bored 
  • I don’t believe you 
  • I don’t care

title: Next Steps
body: Now that you are familiar with some tips for active listening, the next step in your learning is to find out how listening to what is said and how it is said can assist in the detection of deception. In the next module of this course, you will be introduced to the basic principles of detecting deception.

title: Introduction
body:
When you are interviewing someone, how do you know if they are telling the truth?

What principles can you use to help you decide?

This module introduces you to the basic principles of detecting deception.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Analyze audio recordings to establish possible verbal indicators of deception
  • Recognize non-verbal indicators of deception

title: Basic Principles to Detect Deception
body:
Read the statements below, think about how these premises can help you determine whether a person is being deceitful, and write your thoughts in the box provided.

  • Normally socialized people do not like to lie.
  • Lying creates discomfort and complexity, and the discomfort and complexity can change a speaker’s behaviour.
  • The better we are at knowing what behaviour to look for, the better we can be at telling when a person is lying.

How do these help you detect deception? Enter your thoughts and press submit to find out more.

title: Basic Principles to Detect Deception
body:
An individual’s verbal and non-verbal behaviour can change when they attempt to be deceitful. Three different things might happen when a person lies. 
Select each image to find out more.

_items.title: Emotional Reaction
_items.body:
Lying creates discomfort which may be expressed in an Emotional Reaction.

As normally socialized people do not like to lie, while lying, they may display and/or express a range of emotions such as guilt, fear, or excitement.

_items.title: Cognitive Loading
_items.body:
Lying creates complexity which may impact Cognitive Loading.

Cognitive load refers to the amount of effort your brain is using while doing something. Typically, minimal effort is required to tell the truth; however, more effort may be required to keep a lie straight in your head. The cognitively complex task of lying involves fabricating a plausible and convincing tale while attempting to hide and suppress emotional reactions and stress.

_items.title: Attempt to Control Behaviour
_items.body:
Lying creates discomfort and complexity which may be expressed in an Attempt to Control Behaviour.

As normally socialized people do not like to lie, while lying, they may attempt to cover up the lie with physical behaviour such as covering the mouth and/or looking away.
Important:  Keep in mind cultural differences before deciding that the avoidance of eye contact is a possible indicator of deception.

title: Guiding Rules to Detect Deception
body: To assess the reliability of information (i.e. detect deception), you must first establish and identify certain things. Select each tab to understand what these are.

_items.title: Baseline
_items.body:
Baseline behaviour of interviewee

It is important to keep in mind that any of the listed behaviours can be part of a person’s traits or habits. For example, there are people who have a tendency to speak fast, or to mumble. Therefore, it is important that we establish a baseline before we evaluate verbal behaviour. A baseline is the person’s typical verbal behaviour when they are being truthful.

The baseline behaviour is typically established during the orientation phase of the interview as you establish rapport.

_items.title: Context of the situation
_items.body:
Context of the situation

The same thing can have very different significance in different contexts. A few factors can be considered like:

  • Nature of the conversational exchange - is it a formal interview, a casual conversation or a police interrogation?
  • History of the relationship between the parties
  • Congruence - does the verbal or non-verbal fit or contradict the content of the person’s speech? Does the person respond to a speed that coincides with the complexity of the question?
  • Cultural - be aware of the person’s culture (such as language, customs, social behaviour, etc).

For example, nervousness may be the result of an urgent need to travel due to a death in the family. It does not always indicate deception.

_items.title: Clusters of behaviour
_items.body:
Clusters of behaviour

An isolated behaviour is not necessarily an indication of deception, but a group of behaviours may be.

title: Guiding Rules - Tying it Together
body:
Rapport, Baseline, Context, Clusters

Establishing rapport helps you to...

get the baseline behaviour and understand the context of the applicant's situation

  • A cluster of suspicious behaviours may be an indication of deception
  • Deviations from the baseline may be indications of deception. But, a single suspicious behaviour does not provide enough support for deception.

title: Knowledge Check
body:
Let’s do a quick check of what you have learned.
You will be provided with 3 true/false and 1 multiple choice type questions.

After you have answered the questions, please take the time to read the feedback that is associated with your answer choice.

title: Knowledge Check Question 1 of 4
body: The person you are interviewing appears to be nervous. This is an indication that he is being deceptive.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.

There  may be reasons why a person appears to be nervous based on the context of the situation. It is also possible that nervousness is a baseline behaviour. Before making a determination of deception, it is important to: 1) establish the baseline behaviour; 2) understand the context of the situation; and 3) look for clusters of behaviour that may indicate deception.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct.

There  may be reasons why a person appears to be nervous based on the context of the situation. It is also possible that nervousness is a baseline behaviour. Before making a determination of deception, it is important to: 1) establish the baseline behaviour; 2) understand the context of the situation; and 3) look for clusters of behaviour that may indicate deception.

title: Knowledge Check Question 2 of 4
body: A delayed response in answering a question is always an indication of deception.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.

There  may be reasons why a person hesitates before answering a question. Before making a determination of deception, it is important to: 1) establish the baseline behaviour; 2) understand the context of the situation; and 3) look for clusters of behaviour that may indicate deception.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct.

There  may be reasons why a person hesitates before answering a question. Before making a determination of deception, it is important to: 1) establish the baseline behaviour; 2) understand the context of the situation; and 3) look for clusters of behaviour that may indicate deception.

title: Knowledge Check Question 3 of 4
body: While establishing rapport with a person who provided a tip to the CBSA about possible wrongdoing of his former employer, you found it very easy to obtain answers to your questions. He answered all questions without even appearing to think abut them. He appeared very relaxed, and even friendly. In fact he indicated he quit his job and was planning a trip to Mexico next month. When you probed for further details of the alleged wrongdoing, he tried to avoid the question by talking about the trip to Mexico. When asked again, he responded rather rudely, why do you need to know? Finally, he provided you with scant details of the allegation. This behaviour may be an indication of deception on the part of the tipster.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.

While creating rapport, you had established the tipster's baseline behaviour as being friendly and easy-going, but then this behaviour changed when you attempted to solicit certain information. The level of engagement and tone can be considered a cluster of behaviours that deviate from the baseline. It may be that the tipster is being deceptive.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct.

While creating rapport, you had established the tipster's baseline behaviour as being friendly and easy-going, but then this behaviour changed when you attempted to solicit certain information. The level of engagement and tone can be considered a cluster of behaviours that deviate from the baseline. It may be that the tipster is being deceptive.

title: Knowledge Check Question 4 of 4
body:
While establishing rapport with a person who provided a tip to the CBSA about possible wrongdoing of his former employer, you found it very easy to obtain answers to your questions. He answered all questions without even appearing to think abut them. He appeared very relaxed, and even friendly. In fact he indicated he quit his job and was planning a trip to Mexico next month. When you probed for further details of the alleged wrongdoing, he tried to avoid the question by talking about the trip to Mexico. When asked again, he responded rather rudely, why do you need to know? Finally, he provided you with scant details of the allegation.
 
What concepts related to interviewing techniques can help assess the reliability of the information provided by the tipster? Select all that apply.

_items.text: None, the tipster is being deceptive

That is correct.

Awareness of the following concepts is important in trying to detect deception:
Baseline (normal behaviour of interviewee)
Context (of the situation)
Clusters (group of behaviors)

NEVER ASSUME!

title: Next Steps
body:
Now that you know the basic principles of detecting deception, let’s take a closer look at key verbal behaviours you can focus on in your attempts to detect deception.

We will look at how changes in verbal behaviour can assist you in detecting deception.

_items.title: Evasive or generalized responses
_items.body:
Characteristics of evasive or generalized responses

Generalizations and evasions are the responses that liars are most comfortable with.

Remember, normally socialized people do not like to lie. So instead of telling a direct lie, they generalize their response or they evade the question.

Liars will often "beat around the bush". Instead of providing solid detail, someone engaged in deception may have gone on a long-winded explanation with many digressions. They may exhibit unusually poor or selective recall of events.

_items.title: Qualified responses
_items.body:
Characteristics of a qualified response

Sophisticated liars may attempt to use protective verbal coatings such as "At this point in time", "To the best of my recollection" or "If memory serves".

The use of verbal coatings allows the deceptive person an escape or "out" should the truth later be discovered. For example, should the truth later come out, they can claim a faulty memory rather than have to admit to having told a lie.

_items.title: Bolstered Responses
_items.body:
Characteristics of a bolstered response

A person telling the truth does not attempt to convince, they simply state facts. A person who knows that what they are saying is false has a tendency to attempt to convince. This can lead them to bolstering their answers with phrases such as; "To be perfectly honest", "You've got to believe me", or "Honest to God".

_items.title: … delayed responses
_items.body:
Characteristics of a delayed response

Telling lies requires a lot of mental (cognitive) work. Constructing a credible lie, and keeping it separate from the truth, places additional demands on a liar. That may be why people pause before producing a lie and why they might speak more slowly - they need time to decide whether to lie, time to think about what will be most successful, time to invent the details. Lies will often be prefaced by fillers such as "ums", “ahs", sighs, etc. in order to buy time to think.

Another tactic used by some deceptive people is asking you to repeat the question (or repeating the question aloud themselves), thus buying more time to think. On the other hand, quick responses may indicate a person has prepared or rehearsed for a specific question.

_items.title: Mumbling or speaking quietly
_items.body:
Characteristics of mumbling or speaking quietly

Some deceptive people will feel shame or guilt while they lie. This can lead them to mumbling or speaking so low that they are inaudible.

_items.title: Speaking slowly or quickly
_items.body:
Characteristics of speaking slowly or quickly

People typically have a consistent, repetitive and almost rhythmic pattern to their speech. Stress caused from lying could lead to a change in this pattern such as a quicker or slower rate of speech.

_items.title: Changes in pitch
_items.body:
Characteristics of changes in pitch

It is a weII-known cliché that a terrified person will tend to speak with a squeaky voice. This same phenomenon, expressed more subtly, is at play when a person lies. They are experiencing fear while lying, their pitch might become elevated. Most experts agree that a change in a person's pitch frequency is an excellent indicator of deception, but it can be difficult to detect.

_items.title: Inappropriate laughter
_items.body:
Characteristics of inappropriate laughter

Some people will use humour or levity, in inappropriate ways and/or at inappropriate times, in an attempt to camouflage a deceptive response.

Some experts actually refer to this as "duping delight"; such as I'm fooling you and this is fun. If "duping delight" occurs, it will be expressed as a micro-expression of happiness.

Verbal Behaviour That Could Indicate

Deception

N/A

It’s was a... organized aaa... tour. Ya7

her answer.

She even repeats the question or remains silent.

repeating the question and provides no details.

André: OK and in which hotel were you staying?
