title: Next Steps
body: Now that you know how to listen for verbal indicators of deception, let’s turn our attention to the non-verbal indicators.

title: Non-Verbal Behaviours
body:
You have already learned about body language in general. Now we will focus on how to use body language as a source of information about when an individual is not being truthful.

Select each image to be introduced to the following concepts.

_items.title: Body Posture
_items.body:
Posture reflects emotions, interest levels and confidence.

A truthful person displays interest, confidence and emotional involvement.



Honest Body

  • Facing
  • Upright
  • Comfortable, Relaxed
  • Engaged
  • Dynamic

Deceptive Body

  • Oriented Away
  • Slouched
  • Rigid
  • Disengaged
  • Static

_items.title: Barriers
_items.body:
A very common response to emotional discomfort is to create a barrier between the receiver and the source of the discomfort. Arms and legs crossed in a variety positions in front of the body make handy barriers. 

The shift into a crossed position is significant when it coincides with a particular statement or topic.

_items.title: Hand to Face Gestures
_items.body:
These gestures stem from the subconscious desire to stop the flow of words that is causing discomfort. As a child we are likely to place our hands over our mouths. The child will literally slap his hand across the mouth shortly after the lie is uttered. The adult has learned to suppress this gesture to some extent, but still can’t stop the hand from going up to the face. As we get older and more sophisticated, this gesture is modified and the hand is placed near the mouth. 

  • hand to mouth 
  • hand to nose 
  • hand to cheek

_items.title: Grooming Gestures
_items.body:
These gestures are designed to relieve anxiety and to mimic a casual attitude. 

  • adjusting clothing 
  • dusting pants 
  • picking lint 
  • stroking the head 
  • wiping the chin

_items.title: Illustrators
_items.body:
Honest individuals will typically use hand gestures to emphasize and demonstrate the points they wish to make. 

Deceptive individuals, on the other hand, have been observed either suppressing or exaggerating their hand movements. This will result in either greatly curtailed hand movements or movements that are physically larger in scope than those seen during the person’s typical baseline behaviour.

_items.title: Lip Blocking
_items.body: When you don’t like what is coming out of your mouth there is a tendency to want to close it or block it. When this desire is suppressed, it sometimes leaks out in the form of lip blocking.

_items.title: Eye Contact
_items.body:
Conclusions based on eye contact must be drawn very carefully given the wide range between individuals and cultures. 

When assessing eye contact establishing a baseline, or what is normal, is critical. If you establish what the baseline is, and find that the person is avoiding eye contact to an extent greater than what is normal for them, and if this avoidance is coincidental with certain statements or topics, then it can be significant.

title: Visual Activity
body:
Now that you have a general understanding that changes in body language can be indicators of deception, it is time to give it a try.

In this activity, you will be provided 4 scenarios with images within a specific context. Your challenge is to indicate the type of behaviour that is being displayed and whether it may suggest deception.

title: Scenario 1 - Sally
body: Sally’s baseline demeanor prevalent during the orientation and narration phases of an interview related to her involvement in a possible fraud.

title: Scenario 1 - Sally Question 1
body:
Snap-shots of Sally’s demeanor during the cross-examination phase of the same interview. These gestures occurred while Sally was responding to specific questions regarding statements she had made earlier in the interview.

What behaviours are being displayed?
Select all that apply.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  You selected the correct response. Illustrators and lip blocking.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. Illustrators and lip blocking are the correct response.

title: Scenario 1 - Sally Question 2
body:
Snap-shots of Sally’s demeanor during the cross-examination phase of the same interview. These gestures occurred while Sally was responding to specific questions regarding statements she had made earlier in the interview.

Is Sally's change in behaviour suggestive of possible deception?

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  Yes. Sally's behaviour changed from an open posture with a calm demeanor to using illustrators and closing the lips firmly. The timing (when being cross-examined about specific statements) and baseline are important factors to consider.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. Sally's behaviour changed from an open posture with a calm demeanor to using illustrators and closing the lips firmly. The timing (when being cross-examined about specific statements) and baseline are important factors to consider.

title: Scenario 2 - Emmanuelle
body: Emmanuelle’s baseline demeanor prevalent during the orientation and narration phases of an interview related to her involvement in a possible fraud.

title: Scenario 2 - Emmanuelle Question 1
body:
Snap-shot of Emmanuelle’s demeanor during the cross-examination phase of the same interview. Emmanuelle folded her arms while you were probing for additional information. 

What behaviours are being displayed?
Select all that apply.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  You selected the correct response. Barriers.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. Barriers is the correct response.

title: Scenario 2 - Emmanuelle Question 2
body:
Snap-shot of Emmanuelle’s demeanor during the cross-examination phase of the same interview. Emmanuelle folded her arms while you were probing for additional information. 

Is Emmanuelle’s change in behaviour suggestive of possible deception?

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right! Yes. The timing of this behaviour (in response to your probing) and the established baseline behaviour are important factors to consider.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. The timing of this behaviour (in response to your probing) and the established baseline behaviour are important factors to consider.

title: Scenario 3 - Jorge
body: Snapshots of Jorge’s demeanor prevalent throughout the entire interview.

title: Scenario 3 - Jorge Question 1
body:
Snapshots of Jorge’s demeanor prevalent throughout the entire interview. 

What behaviours are being displayed?
Select all that apply.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  Illustrators and lip blocking are the correct response.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. Illustrators and lip blocking are the correct response.

title: Scenario 3 - Jorge Question 2
body:
Snapshots of Jorge’s demeanor prevalent throughout the entire interview. 

Is Jorge’s behaviour suggestive of possible deception?

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  No. In this case, the cluster of non-verbal behaviour displayed by Jorge appears to be his baseline behaviour. If Jorge had stopped using illustrators, this could be an indication of deception. Remember, the timing and baseline are important factors to consider.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. No. In this case, the cluster of non-verbal behaviour displayed by Jorge appears to be his baseline behaviour. If Jorge had stopped using illustrators, this could be an indication of deception. Remember, the timing and baseline are important factors to consider.

title: Scenario 4 - Anna
body: Snapshots of Anna’s demeanor during the orientation phase of the interview.  Anna had requested this interview, as she wanted to provide a tip to the CBSA about concerns that her neighbour was housing “illegal immigrants”. Note, the temperature in the interview room was cold.

title: Scenario 4 - Anna Question 1
body:
Snap-shot of Anna’s demeanor during the narration phase of the same interview. Anna diverted her eyes and raised her finger to her face when asked to explain why she had concerns about her neighbour. 

What behaviours are being displayed?
Select all that apply.

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right!  Hand to face gestures and eye contact are the correct response.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. Hand to face gestures and eye contact are the correct response.

title: Scenario 4 - Anna Question 2
body:
Snap-shot of Anna’s demeanor during the narration phase of the same interview. Anna diverted her eyes and raised her finger to her face when asked to explain why she had concerns about her neighbour. 

Is Anna’s change in behaviour suggestive of possible deception?

_feedback.correct:
Correct

That's right! YES. The timing of this behaviour (in response to your open-ended question) and the established baseline behaviour (especially the initial good eye contact) are important factors to consider.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect

You did not select the correct response. YES. The timing of this behaviour (in response to your open-ended question) and the established baseline behaviour (especially the initial good eye contact) are important factors to consider.

title: Next Steps
body: Now that you know how to watch for and can recognize verbal indicators of deception, let’s conclude this module with some tips for improving success in detecting deception.

title: Reflection
body:
Take the time to think of reasons why we may not be very successful in detecting deception. Write them in the space provided and press submit to view the suggested answer.

What may hinder your ability to detect deception? Enter your thoughts and press submit to see the suggested answer.

_feedback.correct:
Some reasons why we may not be good at detecting deception:

  • No one displays “typical” behaviour 
  • The differences between baseline and deceit are often small 
  • We are too busy to want to know 
  • We focus too much on the verbal message alone 
  • We don’t probe far enough 
  • We become too engaged in the questioning process 
  • We don’t observe the whole body 
  • The person’s baseline is nervous

_incorrect.final:
Some reasons why we may not be good at detecting deception:

  • No one displays “typical” behaviour 
  • The differences between baseline and deceit are often small 
  • We are too busy to want to know 
  • We focus too much on the verbal message alone 
  • We don’t probe far enough 
  • We become too engaged in the questioning process 
  • We don’t observe the whole body 
  • The person’s baseline is nervous

title: Improve Success
body:
Now let’s see suggestions on how you can improve your success  in detecting deception. 

  • Establish and maintain rapport 
  • Avoid contaminating with non-productive behaviour 
  • Exploit the narrative phase 
  • Probe effectively where warranted 
  • Don’t get lost in the questioning 
  • Observe the individual’s whole body 
  • Measure against the baseline established through rapport 
  • Tune into the verbal and the non-verbal 
  • Question observed behaviours 
  • Resist prejudicial reaction to behaviours

title: Summary
body:
• Lying creates discomfort which may be expressed in an emotional reaction
  • Lying creates complexity which may impact cognitive loading
  • Lying creates discomfort and complexity which may be expressed in an attempt to control behaviour

Therefore, to detect deception you must:

  • consider the context;
  • look for clusters; and,
  • learn the individual’s baseline and then look for deviations (which may be an indication of deception).

title: Next Steps
body: Now that you are familiar with the guiding rules to detecting deception, the next step in your learning is to find out how you can get the interviewee talking. In the next module of this course, you will be introduced to four techniques you can use to encourage talking.

title: Introduction - Talking
body:
The challenge in any interview is to use each of the four phases of the interview process effectively.  You must be able to ask the right questions in the right way and display appropriate body language that is conducive to the process.

This module introduces you to basic techniques that will help you meet the goals of the interview process, with particular emphasis on the goals associated with phases 2 and 3.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Distinguish between probing for more information and probing for veracity.

title: Goals of Interviewing Process Revisited
body:
Interview Process

Before proceeding, take the time to refresh your memory of the four phases and their specific goals, by clicking on the icon below.

_items.title: 1. Orientation
_items.body:
Goals in this phase:

  • Establish the purpose of the interview
  • Formally identify the person involved in the interview
  • Establish an adequate level of language comprehension
  • Establish rapport with the person being interviewed

_items.title: 2. Narrative
_items.body:
Goals in this phase:

  • Maintain or enhance rapport
  • Get the interviewee talking

_items.title: 3. Resolution
_items.body:
Goals in this phase:

  • Get the interviewee to accept the established truths or exposed deceptions

_items.title: 4. Cross-Examination
_items.body:
Goals in this phase:

  • Probe the interviewee for more specific details and to seek clarification of statements made in the narration phase

title: Potential Pitfalls in Interviewing
body:
Beginner interviewers have a strong tendency to skip past the narration phase and to dive prematurely into 
cross-examination. 

They have trouble getting the individual to talk freely and as a result they start to do most of the talking. This interferes with their ability to listen carefully and observe. It takes the onus off the person and puts it on the officer. And it changes the tone of the interview for worse, which shuts down the flow of information. 

Four techniques are introduced next. These will assist you in getting the individual to talk freely.

title: Questioning
body:
Questioning is an essential element to any interview process. To elicit the required information you must be able to ask questions in the right way. 

We will start to uncover the content on questioning by looking at two ways to ask questions. We will do this by way of a Q&A that illustrates these two types of questions.

title: Q&A
body:
Let’s take a look at the advantages associated with both types of questions, followed by an activity about their disadvantages.

Select each questions to see the answer.

_items.title: Question 1: What are the two types of questions?
_items.body:
Answer

Open and closed.

_items.title: Question 2: What is the typical response elicited by closed questions?
_items.body:
Answer

Yes, no, or brief response.

_items.title: Question 3: How can you elicit more elaborate responses?
_items.body:
Answer

By asking open questions.

_items.title: Question 4: How do open questions elicit more elaborate responses?
_items.body:
Answer

Open-ended questions kindle conversation by encouraging the other person to elaborate. For instance, if you ask someone to explain, you encourage that person to elaborate when answering the question.

title: Disadvantages
body: Select each type of question to see the associated disadvantages.

_items.title: Open Questions
_items.body:
• May promote misunderstanding if ambiguously worded.
  • Interviewee may not know direction you are going in.
  • Time consuming.
  • May result in unnecessary information. 
  • May open a “Pandora’s box” of woes. 
  • May increase the chances of losing control of the interview.

_items.title: Closed Questions
_items.body:
• Restricts range of response.
  • Interviewee may feel his side of the story not being considered. 
  • May cause interviewee to feel interrogated, cause him to become defensive.
  • Can be irritating or threatening.
  • Unless carefully worded, may let interviewee off the hook by allowing simple “yes” or “no” answers.
  • Can result in misleading assumption/ conclusions about information provided as it discourages disclosure.

title: Summary
body:
Closed-ended questions elicit just a "yes" or "no" or another very brief answer. Open-ended questions kindle conversation by encouraging the other person to elaborate.
Questioning with both open and closed questions is one technique you can use to control the conversation.

title: Probing
body:
Probing is the use of questions, that were developed on the basis of already obtained information, designed to either obtain more information or to test for veracity. 

A probing question is any question that uses information already established, to obtain more information.

A probing question can be either open-ended or closed.

_items.title: What is the key challenge for inexperienced interviewers when probing for more information?
_items.body:
Answer

It is essential for you to act within the confines of your authorities, i.e. to know the law, and then to persist with the question long enough to get the information you need.

title: To get more information
body:
Question 1: I’d like to learn a bit more about your visit to Qinshan at the Great Wall. How did you travel there?

Answer 1: By bus.

 

Question 2: Where in the city did the bus let you off?

Answer 2: At the main bus station.

 

Question 3: What was the name of the main bus station?

Answer 3: I don’t remember; it was a Chinese name.

 

Question 4: Describe the bus station for me, with as much detail as possible.

Answer 4: Well, it was a big building, very busy, with lots of vendors and taxi drivers at the main entrance.

 

Question 5: So it was busy? Describe the actual building for me.

Answer 5: Well, that’s about all I can remember - just very busy. We left and went straight into a restaurant. We were starving after the long bus ride.

 

Question 6: What is the bus station made of?

Answer 6: Ah, brick, I think.

title: To test for veracity
body:
Question 1: What are you doing while in Canada?

Answer 1: Business.
(Result: More detail required. Probe with another open question.)

 

Question 2: Tell me a little bit more about what you are doing?

Answer 2: Selling our company’s lighting product.
(Result: Still more detail required. Probe again.)

 

Question 3: I’ll need to get a few more specific details from you. Can you tell me exactly who you are working for, what your position is and what specifically you will be doing in Canada?

Answer 3: I work for Trans Lumen in Boston. We manufacture solar powered navigational lights. I am their international sales manager. Over the next several days I will be meeting with several railway companies in Toronto to try and generate some interest in buying our products.

(Result: You now have sufficient information to conclude that the person is a business visitor to Canada as defined in s. 187 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations - a foreign national representing a foreign business for the purpose of making sales on behalf of that business, but is not engaged in making sales to general public in Canada. She is not engaged in unauthorized employment and therefore not in violation of IRPA.)

title: Probing to Get More Information
body:
Success in probing to get more information depends on understanding what information is needed. If the issue is work, for example, knowing the legal requirements related to working in Canada will enable you to question effectively. 

So, instead of focusing on what questions you need to ask, focus instead on what is it you need to know - what information is crucial to your decision?

title: Probing - Tying it Together
body:
An examination of any issue begins with the basic question “What do I need to know?”. 

When probing for more information, we speak about breadth or “branching out” in various directions to collect more information. However, when the veracity of any information becomes suspect, you need to “drill down”. Here we are talking about depth which means seizing upon a particular fact and going deeper and deeper into it.

_items.title: What words of advice would an experienced officer have to offer in regards to probing?
_items.body: Experienced officers will tell you that an individual’s lies are only “three questions deep”. In other words, when preparing to be deceptive, an individual will mentally rehearse their story to only about three depth-levels of fact. To discover whether or not the person is fabricating information, an officer must probe below that third layer. By the fourth probing question, the information and/or the individual are usually either “holding together” if truthful, or “falling apart” if deceptive.

title: A Lie is Only Three Questions Deep
displayTitle: A Lie is Only Three Questions Deep
body:
A lie is only three questions deep. When probing for veracity, drill down on verifiable facts.     

When drilling down for depth, try to formulate questions that will require the individual to provide specific and verifiable information. Even if you can’t readily verify the information, the fact that the individual thinks you can, should be enough to either encourage the truth or create significant and observable body-language reactions during deceptive responses.

title: Conclusion
body:
Probing can be subtle or obvious. 

Obvious probing can begin to feel like an interrogation. This works against the objective of maintaining rapport. Subtle probing is more effective in the long run, because it allows you to achieve two important goals - testing the information for truthfulness and maintaining rapport with the individual. 

With practice, you can ask the questions in a casual way that gives the individual the impression that you just want to talk.

title: Probing
body:
Summary
Probing for veracity is a challenging and important skill to master!     
Effective probing results in obtaining the desired results of the interview.
Probing is one technique you can use to control the conversation.

back.title: Let’s begin with an example.
back.body: “I paid Mr. Chee $5,000 to bring me to Canada and he said that once we reached the border he would drop me off and there would be a lady to meet me and she would take me to the restaurant where I was going to work. I could sleep in the basement of the restaurant. Instead, the lady took me to a motel where I had to stay in a room with five other girls and I was expected to wait on tables, dance and do other things for the customers that I did not want to do.”

_items.front:
How would you paraphrase what she said?
Select to see a suggestion.

back.title: How would you paraphrase what she said?
back.body: “You are saying that you paid this man $5,000 to take you to the border and meet a woman who supposedly had arranged your work at a restaurant but instead you were forced to work in the motel bar. Is that right?”

title: Paraphrasing Is…
body:
Paraphrasing is the act of restating what the individual has said, using different words, to confirm for the individual that you have understood their message. 

Once the speaker has offered their own thoughts, you repeat them back to them using your own words but keeping as close as possible to the essence of their message. 

If the speaker agrees with your paraphrase, then you can move on. If not, they can explain further to clarify the message. You can then respond again with another paraphrase, starting with: 
“OK, am I right in saying that . . .” 

You can continue paraphrasing until the speaker confirms your understanding.

title: Uses of Paraphrasing
body:
Paraphrasing can be used during an interview to: 

  • ensure understanding of an ambiguous or complex statement; 
  • encourage a quiet person to continue speaking or contributing; 
  • reinforce an important point; 
  • ensure others understand the statement in a group; 
  • ensure the person hears what they themselves have just said, in the case of a contradictory or illogical statement.

title: Advantages of Paraphrasing
body:
What are the advantages and results of using the technique of paraphrasing? 

  • Demonstrates your interest in what the person is saying, in order to reach a conclusion, solution or decision. 
  • Checks for and validates understanding. 
  • Encourages speaker to provide further information.
  • Demands active listening on interviewer’s part. 
  • Cools the individual’s anger; they feel they are being heard.

title: Summary
body:
Effective paraphrasing results in clear understanding by means of confirming and clarifying meaning.

Paraphrasing is one technique you can use to control the conversation.

title: What is Mirroring?
body: Select each option to find the elaborated answers.

back.title: Mirroring the individual’s words
back.body:
Mirroring is the act of intentionally duplicating a person’s words to encourage expansion. The principle of mirroring is based on the fact that the person listening should give back to the speaker whatever they have heard and understood; that is, what he thinks he has understood. 
This has the effect of encouraging the interviewee to expand on the topic. 
Furthermore, the technique of mirroring the words forces you to pay attention to the person’s words. This encourages active listening on your part and leaves the individual with the feeling of having been heard. The result is more rapport and more information.

back.title: Mirroring the individual’s body language
back.body: Mirroring is also referred to as “matching” or “pacing”. In this regard, the technique is based on the assumption that we tend to feel comfortable with people who communicate in the same manner that we do. People feel comfortable when you do the same things that they do, provided your imitations are not obvious.

back.title: Mirroring the individual’s tone
back.body:
Tone matching is probably one of the more important of the mirroring skills; if the tone is not synchronized, the speaker may be alienated .

When mirrored effectively, the speaker identifies with, and feels more comfortable with, an interviewer who mirrors their communication style; and the quality of the discussion also improves.

title: What is Mirroring?
body:
When you mirror someone, which we do every day with our friends and colleagues, we are subconsciously modelling them. It can be verbal and/or non-verbal as demonstrated by body language. Mirroring may be done by copying another person’s gestures, posture, smile, voice, tone or other body language. Overall, the quality of communication improves when two people are using the same representational system. 

Next, we will look at some of the positive influences of mirroring, followed by obstacles to effective mirroring.

title: The Positive Influence of Mirroring
body:
The use of mirroring has positive influences on the interview for both the interviewer and the interviewee.

 

Interviewer

Obtains more information through concentration as effective mirroring requires active listening. 
 

Interviewee

Feels heard and understood. 
 

Mirroring builds rapport and facilitates communication for both.

The combination of understanding, listening and expressing comprehension, is the ideal engine for every understanding discussion.

title: Obstacles to Effective Mirroring
body: Select each option to see examples.

_items.front: Using an accusatory or demeaning tone

back.title: Using an accusatory or demeaning tone
back.body: Using an accusatory or demeaning tone when mirroring the individual’s words, puts the individual “on guard” and critically limits the amount of information that will be forthcoming .

back.title: Use of confrontational body language
back.body: Use of confrontational body language may lead the individual to sense that the interviewer is hostile or argumentative even before the interview starts.

back.title: Not actively listening
back.body: Not actively listening may make the individual feel that you don’t care about him or his problems or issues. This has a major impact on the flow of information.

title: Summary
body:
Effective mirroring results in the interviewee feeling at ease with the situation, which then opens the conversation.

The technique of mirroring is complementary to active listening. Active listening and mirroring are the most intimately related and most productive elements of every interview. 

The mirroring of words, body and/or tone is one technique you can use to control the conversation.

title: Summary
body:
Now that you’ve been introduced to these four techniques, we will conclude this module with a short summary.

The narration phase is essential. Without it you cannot be fully in control of the interview and they are unlikely to be able to cross-examine as effectively. 
To succeed in the narration phase, you can rely upon three of the techniques presented:  open/closed questions, mirroring and paraphrasing. 

Even though you have asked an open question, you may not always get that expected abundance of information from the individual. When the initial open question is met with a short answer, you will want to use the techniques of mirroring, perhaps paraphrasing and then (usually) follow up with another open question. 

Success in the cross-examination phase relies on the ability to probe effectively.

title: Next Steps
body: Now that you are familiar with four techniques you can use to encourage talking, the next step in your learning is to find out how you can deal with difficult situations. In the next module of this course, you will be introduced to the topic of dealing with difficult situations.

title: Introduction
body:
To succeed at interviewing you must:

  • Establish and maintain rapport; and 
  • Consciously divide your interview into four phases. 

 

But the questions arise:

  • What do you do with an angry or hostile person? 
  • How are you supposed to “establish rapport” with someone who is shouting at you? 
  • How can you even begin the orientation phase with a hostile individual?

title: Introduction
body:
The reality is that working as a CBSA E&I officer you will encounter individuals who are scared, or frustrated, or anxious, or a mixture of all of the above and who behave in an angry or hostile manner as a result. 

This module introduces you to an approach to defuse the anger so that you can get to the process of building rapport and solving the problem.

The process relies on using much of what you have already learned, albeit in a particular way.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
After completing this module, you will be able to:

  • Identify the techniques used in each phase of the C.A.L.M. approach to dealing with difficult situations.

title: Case Study
body:
Before looking at the C.A.L.M. approach, let’s start this module by looking at a fictional case study.
 
Instructions:

  • Access the resource tab above. 
  • Select and open the document called “Case_Study”.
  • Save it to you desktop.

 

Next:

  • Read the case, think about the techniques you would use to diffuse the situation and answer the question.
  • Make sure to save the document on your desktop as we will revisit your answer throughout this module.

title: C.A.L.M.
body:
How can you handle the various behaviours and emotions that you will encounter on the job? A systematic approach may help. 

C.A.L.M. is such an approach to defusing hostility. This rational and methodical approach is designed to head off trouble before it gets out of control. 

This approach, introduced next, builds on the skills and knowledge covered earlier in this course.

back.body: Acknowledge the Other Person’s Feelings and Emotions
Listen Actively to What the Person is Saying
Mediate Between the Person and the Requirements

title: Calm Yourself
body:
During the first phase of the C.A.L.M. process it is important that you do not get caught up in the issues/emotions at hand. You need to suspend judgement, remain in control of your own emotions and keep your ultimate goal in mind (a successful interview). 

In an interview involving a hostile individual, there are two possible outcomes: either you follow the person into their world or you bring the individual back into your world. 

Remember - your goal should be to bring the person into your world!

title: Techniques to Calm Yourself
body:
Until you are able to calm the other person, it will be impossible to convince them of the merits of a more reasonable approach to the problem and then proceed to your goal. 

There are some techniques you may employ to calm yourself, and then calm others you are interacting with.  

Select the images below to find out what these techniques are.

back.body:
• Display an open style body language 
  • Use the person’s name 
  • Pacing

• Avoid triggers
  • Be aware of, and don’t react to things that trigger your own anger

title: Case Study Revisited 1/2
body:
Time to revisit the case study by referring back to your answer and answering a few more questions.

1. In answering the question:

What techniques will you use to diffuse the situation so that you can complete this stage and advance to the next stages of the interview?

Did you mention that it would be important for you to first calm yourself?

_feedback.correct: Clearly Mr. Saumon is angry so it is important for your to remain calm.

_incorrect.final: Clearly Mr. Saumon is angry so it is important for your to remain calm.

title: Case Study Revisited 2/2
body:
2. From the techniques introduced under the calm step, select all those that you included in your answer to the question.

Do you think these techniques were successful?

_items.text: Display an open style body language
Be aware of, and don’t react to things that trigger your own anger

_feedback.correct:
Unfortunately, none of these techniques worked in calming Mr. Saumon. 
We will finish the “C” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “A” that may help.

_incorrect.final:
Unfortunately, none of these techniques worked in calming Mr. Saumon. 
We will finish the “C” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “A” that may help.

title: Summary
body:
In general, behaviour breeds behaviour. 

You can choose your behaviour but only if you remain calm. 

By remaining calm you can influence the situation by bringing the individual into your world.

This may not always have the desired effect, but doing these techniques will assist in preventing escalation of the situation. Other techniques may also help.

title: Acknowledge the Other Person’s Feelings and Emotions
body:
If people feel they are being understood, and that there is some empathy or sympathy, anger will often dissipate. 

To bring the other person into your world, and show how you understand them, it is important for you to:

  • identify the emotions;
  • acknowledge the situation the person is going through may be frustrating or stressful; 
  • demonstrate your desire to help.

title: Acknowledge the Other Person’s Feelings and Emotions
body:
Be careful not to minimize the feelings experienced. 

What may seem like nothing to you may appear, to the individual, to be the biggest obstacle facing them in their life. It’s difficult to know what lies below the surface of the issue.

title: Techniques for Showing Empathy and Understanding
displayTitle: Techniques for Showing Empathy and Understanding
body:
1. Ask open questions.

Do you recall the advantages associated with open questions?

_items.title: Select to refresh your memory.
_items.body:
• Allows freedom of response 
  • Brings out feelings, attitudes and opinions 
  • Assists evaluation of validity and reliability of information 
  • Gives you a chance to think 
  • Helps establish rapport 
  • Helps interviewee feel his side of story is being considered 
  • Helps provide an overview

title: Techniques for Showing Empathy and Understanding
body:
2. Use “feeling” words that indicate an understanding of the emotions involved.

Here are some examples:

  • I can appreciate that this situation seems unfair, and… 
  • I understand that this situation is frustrating… 
  • I can see/hear that this situation is upsetting… 

 

3. Allow  the person the opportunity to (appropriately) blow-off steam. 

Intervene with empathy at the appropriate time.

title: Case Study Revisited
body:
Time to revisit the case study by referring back to your answer and answering a few more questions.

1. In answering the question:

What techniques will you use to diffuse the situation so that you can complete     this stage and advance to the next stages of the interview?

Did you mention that it would be important for you to do any of the following?

  • identify the emotions
  • acknowledge the situation the person is going through may be frustrating or stressful 
  • demonstrate your desire to help

_feedback.correct:
Mr. Saumon appears to be angry, frustrated and concerned about his future. By identifying these emotions, you can now acknowledge that the situation may be stressful.  

Your attempts at empathy, coupled with your own calm demeanor had a minor impact on Mr. Saumon’s behavior. 

We will finish the “A” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “L” that may help.

_incorrect.final:
Mr. Saumon appears to be angry, frustrated and concerned about his future. By identifying these emotions, you can now acknowledge that the situation may be stressful.  

Your attempts at empathy, coupled with your own calm demeanor had a minor impact on Mr. Saumon’s behavior. 

We will finish the “A” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “L” that may help.

title: Summary
body:
An individual’s emotions may be born out of fear, frustration, anxiety or some combination of all three. 

They are in unfamiliar surroundings, in the middle of an unfamiliar process, so it is natural that they will be stressed, some more than others. 

By remaining calm and acknowledging their feelings you can influence the situation by bringing the individual into your world.

title: Listen Actively to What the Person is Saying
body:
Use active listening techniques such as mirroring, paraphrasing the emotion, nodding, and pausing. This will ensure you have correctly heard the person’s issues. In other words, do not interrupt. 

Ask the person if you have correctly understood their position.

title: Case Study Revisited
body:
Time to revisit the case study by referring back to your answer and answering a few more questions.

1. In answering the question:

What techniques will you use to diffuse the situation so that you can complete     this stage and advance to the next stages of the interview?

Did you mention the use of  active listening techniques such as mirroring, paraphrasing the emotion, nodding, and pausing?

_feedback.correct:
In using these techniques, you are indicating to Mr. Saumon that you have correctly heard and understood his concerns. 

We will finish the “L” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “M” that will tie it all together.

_incorrect.final:
In using these techniques, you are indicating to Mr. Saumon that you have correctly heard and understood his concerns. 

We will finish the “L” with a summary, and then look at other techniques associated with “M” that will tie it all together.

title: Summary
body:
It is difficult  for someone to remain hostile if they feel they are being listened to and being understood.

By remaining calm, acknowledging their feelings and actively listening you can influence the situation by bringing the individual into your world.

title: Mediate Between the Person and the Requirements
body:
If you have successfully identified the person’s concerns, and listened and shown some empathy during the process, it is very likely the person will begin to see you in a new light. 

Instead of a barrier to getting what they want, you will be seen as a problem solver, someone who can assist the person in reaching their goals. 

It is impossible for most people to remain hostile when they are being assisted, understood and given a chance to express themselves.

title: Mediating Activity
body:
Let’s explore this step with a scenario activity.

In this activity, you will be provided two scenarios. Your challenge is to indicate the best course of action to mediate between the person and the requirements to obtain pertinent information.

Feedback will be provided that will specify a technique that could be used to address the situation.

title: Scenario 1 of 2 - Mediating Interviewee Pressures and Requirements
displayTitle: Scenario 1 of 2 - Mediating Interviewee Pressures and Requirements
body:
During an interview with a person of interest in a particular case, the individual mentions that he’d be really embarrassed if his wife found out that he is being questioned. He’s concerned about what his wife would think of him and is becoming hostile. This concern of embarrassment is impeding your goal of obtaining the required information.

In following the C.A.L.M. approach, you have remained calm and calmed him down by actively listening to and acknowledging his concerns. From the options below select the best course of action for you to take to advance to the next step to mediate between the person and the requirements.

_items.text: Suggest in general terms that he will feel better by explaining the situation to his wife.
Tell him that it doesn't matter what his wife thinks. He should just cooperate.
Tell him you need this information and that's all there is to it.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct. 

This option corresponds to the technique of looking for motivators (such as money, time, reputation, family) that you can use to mediate between the person (in this example, feelings of embarrassment leading to hostility impeding the flow of information) and the requirement for you to obtain pertinent information.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct.

By choosing this option, you may be closing down communication. You are showing a lack of empathy and an indication that you do not want to understand. The best course of action would be for you to “suggest in general terms that he will feel better by explaining the situation to his wife”.


This option corresponds to the technique of looking for motivators (such as money, time, reputation, family) that you can use to mediate between the person (in this example, feelings of embarrassment leading to hostility impeding the flow of information) and the requirement for you to obtain pertinent information.

title: Scenario 2 of 2 - Mediating Interviewee Hostile Blaming and Requirements
displayTitle: Scenario 2 of 2 - Mediating Interviewee Hostile Blaming and Requirements
body:
While undertaking an interview with a hostile person, you encounter finger-pointing and blaming. He says the Agency didn’t give him enough time to complete the required documentation and that he does not know what you want and why you want it. This is impeding your goal of obtaining the required information.

In following the C.A.L.M. approach, you have remained calm and calmed him down by actively listening to and acknowledging his concerns. From the options below select all the actions you could take to advance to the next step to mediate between the person and the requirements.

_items.text: Ask questions to find out what he doesn't understand, and then clarify the issue.
Present options, allow him the opportunity to have some control in the decision making process.
Seek agreement on a course of action.
Follow through on the agreed course of action.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct. 

This option corresponds to the technique of looking for motivators (such as money, time, reputation, family) that you can use to mediate between the person (in this example, feelings of embarrassment leading to hostility impeding the flow of information) and the requirement for you to obtain pertinent information.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct.

By choosing this option, you may be closing down communication. You are showing a lack of empathy and an indication that you do not want to understand. The best course of action would be for you to “suggest in general terms that he will feel better by explaining the situation to his wife”.


This option corresponds to the technique of looking for motivators (such as money, time, reputation, family) that you can use to mediate between the person (in this example, feelings of embarrassment leading to hostility impeding the flow of information) and the requirement for you to obtain pertinent information.

title: Mediating Techniques
body:
The following techniques were introduced in the feedback to the scenarios:

  • Clarify the issue, ask questions.
  • Present options, allow the person the opportunity to have some control in the decision making process.
  • Look for motivators. Anything that will motivate the person to calm down and start to move forward in the process: money, time, reputation, family.
  • Seek agreement on a course of action. The individual is far more likely to follow through if they have agreed with the course of action.
  • Follow through on the agreed course of action.

title: Case Study Revisited
body:
Time to revisit the case study by referring back to your answer and answering a few more questions.

1. In answering the question:

What techniques will you use to diffuse the situation so that you can complete     this stage and advance to the next stages of the interview?

Did you try to find ways to mediate between Mr. Saumon’s concerns and the requirement to obtain information to facilitate the removal process?

_feedback.correct:
Now that you have listened to Mr. Saumon’s concerns you are ready to mediate between them and the requirement to obtain information to facilitate the removal process. 

You can start addressing his concerns by explaining the process to him, in regard to handcuffs and any money he may have in his possession.  

You may want to say for example,

  • “Let’s see what we can do about making sure your money is secured.”
  • “By working together, we might be able to find a solution to being seen handcuffed in public.”
  • “It may be easier on your family if you cooperate with the process.”  

Although Mr. Saumon didn’t completely calm down and continued to vent periodically, the interview was a success in that the required information was obtained from him.

We will finish the “M” with a summary, and then continue to see how venting should be addressed.

_incorrect.final:
Now that you have listened to Mr. Saumon’s concerns you are ready to mediate between them and the requirement to obtain information to facilitate the removal process. 

You can start addressing his concerns by explaining the process to him, in regard to handcuffs and any money he may have in his possession.  

You may want to say for example,

  • “Let’s see what we can do about making sure your money is secured.”
  • “By working together, we might be able to find a solution to being seen handcuffed in public.”
  • “It may be easier on your family if you cooperate with the process.”  

Although Mr. Saumon didn’t completely calm down and continued to vent periodically, the interview was a success in that the required information was obtained from him.

We will finish the “M” with a summary, and then continue to see how venting should be addressed.

title: Summary
body: By remaining calm, acknowledging their feelings, actively listening and mediating between the person and the requirements, you can influence the situation by bringing the individual into your world.

title: Self-Reflection
body:
Take the time to reflect on what the C.A.L.M. model means to you by typing your thoughts in the box below. You may want to comment on the techniques introduced.

Calming techniques include:  using the person’s name, using a open body style, being aware of triggers and not reacting to them, using active listening techniques such as mirroring, paraphrasing the emotion, nodding, and pausing; showing empathy, using feeling words; and presenting options, looking for motivators, clarifying issues, seeking agreement and following through.

Do you see yourself being able to use them? (As this is a self-reflection, there is no feedback.)

  • Calm Yourself
  • Acknowledge the Other Person’s Feelings and Emotions 
  • Listen Actively to What the Person is Saying
  • Mediate Between the Person and the Requirements

title: Difficult Situations Encountered
body: While conducting interviews you will encounter various difficult situations. Let’s look at two (2) examples and how they were handled.

_items.title: Purpose of  the interview
_items.body: The client was asked to come to the CBSA office to discuss her current status in Canada.

_items.title: Description  of the person
_items.body: She was born in Iran and had made a refugee claim in Canada. From there she applied to become a permanent resident and then a Canadian citizen. She recently had her refugee claim vacated and her citizenship revoked for misrepresentation. She is now a foreign national.

_items.title: The Interview process
_items.body: She seemed to have some mental health issues which led her to respond to questions with irrelevant information. She was constantly going off on tangents and did not wish to answer certain questions as she believed the answers were none of the CBSA’s business. She became angry and stated she did not want to return to Iran. She then stopped responding to questions.

_items.title: How the  situation was resolved
_items.body: Throughout the interview the officer remained calm and collected. The officer was able to set aside the irrelevant information and redirect tangents to the questions asked. By asking short, clarifying questions, the officer was able to gather the information needed. The officer made sure that the client knew that her concerns were being heard and that her issues where important.  Ultimately, the officer was able to take control of the interview by being self-controlled, perseverant, and adaptable and by being aware of the client’s triggers for becoming angry. This interview was deemed successful.

_items.title: Purpose of  the interview
_items.body: The subject was interviewed to gather intelligence regarding narcotics smuggling at the border.

_items.title: Description  of the person
_items.body: He was a Canadian citizen who was employed as a truck driver. He didn’t have a criminal record but according to database checks he had some business ties to another individual who had been intercepted with narcotics at the border.

_items.title: The Interview process
_items.body: The subject was a very close friend and distant relative of the individual on whom the officer wanted to gather information. When the subject realized the motives of the questioning he became very defensive and his loyalty to his friend became an issue and an obstacle during the interview.

_items.title: How the  situation was resolved
_items.body: The officer took the time to listen to the subject’s concerns without interrupting and acknowledged the relationship between the subject and the other individual. The officer respectfully accepted the subject’s reluctance to discuss certain topics and reoriented the line of questioning to focus on peripheral topics. The information the officer gathered ended up being somewhat limited but some important information was gathered.

title: Summary
body:
In a situation involving an angry individual, if you can demonstrate the intent to suspend judgement, and attempt to understand the angry person without getting angry yourself, you will be more likely to be able to defuse his anger. 

Remember - your goal should be to bring the person into your world!

title: Confirm Participation
body:
You must confirm in ESS My Learning that you have completed this course:

  1. Close this page to update your completion progress
  2. Click the Confirm Participation link in the Confirm Participation section located at the bottom of the Course Description page

title: Q&A
body: Select the question to see the answer.

_items.title: Question 1 - What is venting?
_items.body: Venting is an emotional release combining irrational behaviour with a high level of energy output.

_items.title: Question 2 - Is venting always a bad thing?
_items.body:
In some cases, venting can be a good thing. When someone is upset, the opportunity to vent allows them to get their feelings off their chest and to reveal, albeit loudly, exactly what is bothering them. 

After they get their feelings out, that is when you can have a constructive conversation with them.

_items.title: Question 3 - How long does venting typically last?
_items.body: Most people cannot engage in a high level vent for very long (15 to 30 seconds). Quite often, a venting session is immediately followed by a low energy level and signs of remorse on the individual’s part.

_items.title: Question 4 - Is there a right time to intervene when a person is venting?
_items.body: Yes, there is an appropriate time to intervene using the timed verbal intervention technique which is explained next.

title: Timed Verbal Intervention to Venting
body:
Knowing what to say is important, and equally important is knowing when to speak. 

The typical vent includes both peaks and valleys of intensity (shown below). Peaks are short in duration (approximately under 30 seconds). In using the timed verbal intervention, you allow the vent to continue and refrain from interrupting during the peaks - speak only during the valleys. In doing so you avoid feeding the fire while it is blazing.

title: Practise Makes Perfect
body:
The only way to become proficient with these techniques is to practice them. That being said, you should resist the urge to create conflict just to get the chance to practice. However, there are different ways of practising, or simulating a conflict, without having to be personally involved in a real-life conflict situation; such as mental role playing or visualisation. 

Select the images below to see some suggestions for practicing your new skills.

NOTE: Athletes, politicians and law enforcement officers do this all the time. It is not uncommon for athletes to mentally rehearse an entire game prior to it taking place.

back.body: Unfortunately, during the course of our daily lives, we experience or witness conflict regularly. Next time you see/hear something happening, imagine yourself in the situation and think about how you would respond.

Television is a great source of hostile/irate subjects or individuals, so next time you are sitting watching a favourite show and you see/hear an irate/hostile person portrayed, put yourself in the shoes of the person to whom the hostility is directed and think about what you would have said in response.

title: Advantages
body: Select each type of question to see the associated advantages.

_items.title: Open Questions
_items.body:
• Allows freedom of response 
  • Brings out feelings, attitudes and opinions 
  • Assists evaluation of validity and reliability of information 
  • Gives you a chance to think 
  • Helps establish rapport 
  • Helps interviewee feel his side of story is being considered 
  • Helps provide an overview

_items.title: Closed Questions
_items.body:
• Restricts range of response 
  • Controls the pace of interview 
  • Gets to the point / Gets back on topic
  • Gathers data quickly
  • Limits debate where none is wanted
  • Can be used to establish precise, comprehensive, details answers
  • Can be used to check understanding and test for agreement
